title: Colors
content: Color in typography isn’t decoration, it’s function. Text color defines priority, mood, and readability. Primary text should always have the highest contrast against the background, while secondary and tertiary text should step down gradually.
Overusing bright or saturated colors for body text reduces comfort and focus. Good typography uses color to guide the eye, not distract it.

title: Scaling
content: Scale defines the relationship between text sizes. A consistent scale creates rhythm and predictability, while random sizes create noise.
Headings, subheadings, and body text should follow a clear progression, often based on ratios. Good scale makes content feel intentional and structured. Bad scale makes even good fonts feel wrong.

title: Hierarchy
content: Hierarchy organizes content by importance. It guides readers through information, helping them understand what to focus on first.
Effective hierarchy uses size, weight, color, and spacing to differentiate elements. Clear hierarchy improves comprehension and retention.

title: Spacing & Rythm
content: Spacing controls how text breathes. Line-height, margins, and paragraph spacing affect readability more than font choice. Tight spacing feels aggressive; loose spacing feels calm.
Consistent vertical rhythm helps users scan content naturally. If spacing is inconsistent, the design feels chaotic, even if everything else is correct.

title: Contrast & Emphasis
content: Contrast is what makes text readable and meaningful. This includes color contrast, weight contrast, and size contrast. Emphasis should be used sparingly to highlight key information. When everything is emphasized, nothing is. Strong typography uses contrast with intention, allowing important content to stand out without shouting.
